Extract from Inspector Game's report on the French Bay Indian Day School visited on June 10, 1940:

The conductor pipes from the eaves at the rear of the school are again in need of repair and also the screen between the toilets.
Ottawa, June 28, 1940.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the French Bay Indian Day School on the 16th instant, Inspector Game states that the conductor pipes from the eaves at the rear of the school are again in need of repair and also the screen between the toilets.

As these improvements will not involve any heavy expenditure, you may arrange for having the necessary work done during the summer holidays.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. Donald Robertson,
Indian Agent,
Chippawa Hill, Ont.

Form No. I.A. 518
Extract from Inspector Game's report on the French Bay Indian Day School visited on May 8, 1942.

Recommendations:

(1) A new floor in the school
(2) Repairs to woodshed door
(3) Repairs to the fence by the urinal beside the boys' water closet. The urinal is now exposed to the road and passers-by.
Ottawa,
May 23, 1948.

Dear Sir:

In reporting on his inspection of the French Bay School on the 8th instant, Inspector Game writes:

"(1) A new floor in the school.
(2) Repairs to woodshed door.
(3) Repairs to the fence by the urinal beside the boys' water closet. The urinal is now exposed to the road and passers-by."

Please let me have an estimate of the cost of putting a new floor in this school.

Items (2) and (3) will not involve any heavy expenditure and you should have the necessary work done at once.

Yours truly,

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. D. Robertson,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill, Ont.
Sir,

I have the honor to refer to Department letter NO. 31-I-5, dated May 23rd, regarding the French Bay School.

I beg to say, the material for a new floor would cost about $90.00, this would cover the whole class room, if the same kind of flooring that is now on could be purchased it would only require a strip about nine by fifteen feet, this would cover from the entrance to back of the stove, which is really the only part that is badly in need of repairing, this flooring costs from $125.00 to $150.00 per thousand feet. I would try and have this work done by Indian Labour.

Your obedient servant,
Don. Robertson,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.
Ottawa,
July 20, 1948.

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of the 16th instant, with reference to the flooring required for the French Bay School. As the flooring will cost over $50.00 purchase will have to be made through our Purchasing Branch. Consequently you should let me have specific information regarding the kind of flooring that is needed. I note that you estimate the cost of the flooring at $90.00. If you let me know the name and address of the firm from whom you secured this quotation, it is possible that we will be able to get authority for local purchase.

Yours truly,

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Mr. D. Robertson,
Indian Agent,
Chippewa Hill, Ont.
Sir,

I have the honor to refer to Department letter No. 31-I-5, dated July 20th, regarding flooring for the French Bay Indian Day School.

I beg to say, the estimate of $90.00 was secured from Mr. Robert McVittie, Southampton, Ontario, for six hundred feet \(\frac{3}{4}\) maple flooring, this class room is twenty by thirty feet and this class of flooring costs $150.00 per thousand feet.

Your obedient servant,
[Signature]
Don. Robertson,
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa.

Extract from Inspector Game's report on the French Bay Indian Day School visited on April 26, 1944.

The accommodations should be improved in the following respects:

(1) A new wood shed door.
(2) An outside door for the school.
(3) A lock and hasp for the supply cupboard in the class room.
(4) Urgent repairs for the fence screens by the water closets.
(5) Decoration of the class room and repairing of the plaster.
Ottawa,
May 12, 1946.

Mr. D. Robertson, Indian Agent, Chippawa Hill, Ont.

In reporting on his inspection of the French Bay School Inspector Game recommends:

1. A new wood shed door.
2. An outside door for the school.
3. A lock and hasp for the supply cupboard in the classroom.
4. Urgent repairs for the fence screens by the water closets.

None of the above recommendations will involve any heavy expenditure and all of them should receive immediate attention.

You should also obtain and forward for our consideration an estimate of the cost of decorating the classroom and repairing the plaster.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I wish to refer to Department letter NO. 31-1-5, dated May 12th, regarding the French Bay School.

Regarding NO. 3, the lock and hasp has been put on the supply cupboard.

Regarding NOs. 1, 2, and 4, these repairs have been under way since last fall but to date have not been completed but will be as soon as possible.

Regarding decorating the class room, this would cost about $100.00. I may say that this class room was decorated in December 1937. The outside has not been painted for years and should be repainted, this would cost about $55.00.

Don. Robertson,
Indian Agent.
Ottawa,
June 8, 1944.

Mr. D. Robertson, Indian Agent, Chippawa Hill, Ont.

I have your letter of the 31st ultimo, in which you state that the classroom at the French Bay Day School could be redecorated and the outside of the school painted for a total amount of $150. I presume the amount mentioned includes both material and labour, but you do not state in your letter if these are quotations you have received from some responsible painter or whether you recommend purchasing the material and having some Indian do the necessary work. Please let me hear from you regarding this and, in the event of material being required, you should forward a requisition so that purchase may be made through our Purchasing Branch.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

It will require 1½ gallon of white, 1½ gallon of cream and 1 gallon buff paint, also ½ gallon of varnish for the interior and 3 gallon of white and ½ gallon of green for the exterior.

Dear Mr. Phelan,

We arrived here on the 23rd, and I am very pleased with the site and the school. The house is in fair shape, thus the reason for writing to you.

The agent, Mr. Robertson, is at present on site.

The house is very dirty inside; it needs an immediate redecorating and painting job, also some new window glass, and screen doors. There is
very little furniture, namely one bed, dresser and stand, one small table, four chairs and a cook stove.

I would ask that another bed and dresser be bought, a large kitchen table, and a Studer lounge in Buttefield and a small living room table. There is but one small coal oil lamp. Would it be possible to purchase an Aladdin coal oil lamp, as they are very bright, and easy on the eyes.

There is no box stove for winter heating, and as the evenings are now quite cool, this could be used more, also needed are a couple of small rugs and an indoor sanitary closet.

I appreciate that there is quite a list the Hope Relais, but apparently we are harbored in the teachings for a number of years, consequently it needs immediate attention.
Immediate action to make us comfortable will be forthcoming.

Yours very truly,

Sir:

I have the honor to acknowledge your letter of April 25th last—No. 15397—regarding repairs of Teachers' Dwellings on this Reserve.

As requested I herewith enclose a list of probable cost of the work and material required.

In explanation I am obliged to inform the Dept. that much of the line touching is badly decayed and I think it will take the full amount I have estimated.

The cistern for soft water is on the outside and the pump in it was a very small wooden pump and on account of it being exposed and not properly protected the frost has split the pump and made it useless.

I propose to have the new pump inside of the house and the cistern properly secured from the frost with a covering of earth on the plank.

On account of the lightness of the soil, the wind has blown it away from the platform of the hard water well and made a hole about the platform about one ft deep, making the load of gravel necessary.

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, Ontario,

As teacher of the French Bay Indian School,
on the Longue Reserve I beg to submit to the
department the subjoined report on the condition
of the teacher's dwelling at this place and to request
the department to make the following repairs and im-
provements during the approaching mid-summer
vacation.

The Indian Department placed me in charge of the
French Bay Indian School on the 1st day of February
1874, over seventeen years ago. I have been in charge
each consecutive year since that date. Throughout these
years I have exercised the utmost care to keep down
all unnecessary expenses both in connection with
the school and the teacher's dwelling.

When I came here over seventeen years ago my
family consisted of but two small children, myself
and myself. My family consists now of eight members:
six children, their mother and myself a total of eight.
The accommodation which was adequate seventeen
years ago is entirely inadequate today.

There is just one small room downstairs in the
house for a living room. This room is 15 ft. by 10 ft. 4 in.
with a 10 ft. ceiling. This small room is all that can
be used for both a living room and kitchen for
a family of eight. This small room has but one small
window. The window faces the east and is so located
that less than an hour's sun can possibly enter
the room during the twenty-four hours of day.

There is a wood-shed attached to the main building
finished on the outside identically like the main
part of the dwelling house and is connected to the
little kitchen living room by a door giving convenient passage from one to the other. What I desire the Department to do is to have this wood-shed lathed and plastered and a proper floor placed in it so as to convert it into a comfortable living room or rather kitchen for either winter or summer use. It would require another window. This would make it into a well-lighted airy and very convenient addition to the little room we are now compelled to use for both kitchen and living room and would add immensely to the health and comfort of myself and family at but a small financial outlay to the Department.

In addition to this I beg to suggest that the house be sided with steel sheeting and that the shutters which are largely rotted to pieces, be repaired and both to be then painted in colours to suit the teacher and his family. The building is so deteriorating by rain, wind and weather and the present siding so loose and open that it would be an act of economy to have this done even if the comfort of the teacher and his family were left entirely out of consideration.

Hoping to hear from the Department at its convenience. I am your humble servant,

T.J. Wallace

Teacher.

Dear Sir,

I called on the Bishop of Algoma today and he lordship showed me a letter from the Indian Department in which complaints are made by the Church of England school at Garden River that the Public School Inspector states "that the teachers employed there are generally those who can find no other place and have no legal qualifications, and that Indian schools above all others require teachers who know how to teach them since the work is a failure."

As I am the Church of England missionary at Garden River and the school is in a state under my charge and I examine scholars and give instructions to the best of my knowledge, and also taught the school entirely for three months while teacher was sick and besides having been acquainted with this school and these Indian schools for thirty years, you will grant I think that I might say a word in its defense.

You will agree with me that the charges are of a grave and sweeping character especially when we consider what they are.
made by one who sees the school for an hour or two once or twice a year, more often than twice.

It is rather singular and scarcely consistent that Mr. McCaig stated at his last visit "that the school was better than he had ever seen it before—referring to attendance of scholars especially."

Moreover as his lordship has already stated, the remarks are untrue. As far from being the fact that the teachers would find no other place, we have had the greatest difficulty in getting the teachers we so desired. The school was kept untaught because no one could be convinced or incompetent—but we kept the position for Mr. Kane who was one of the best teachers that could be found having taught successfully in white schools in different places but he left us because it was so difficult to secure attendance of children notwithstanding her ability and accomplishments.

When we consider that it is very seldom that Indian children get away long enough at school to get beyond the second reader—and the simple rules of arithmetic—one fails to see why any great scholarship is required on the part of the Indians. The school inspectors notwithstanding, my experience is that the great difficulty to get the children to school. I make continual visits to the homes and school from pulpit, but still it is the difficulty still over the same—but then should not be charged against school or teacher but the innate hatred of the Indian children for school and neglect of parents.

Yours truly,

J. Frost

Department of Indian Affairs:
OTTAWA, 12th December, 1902

The Deputy Superintendent General:

Mr Public School Inspector McCaig, who visits the Church of England School on the Garden River reserve, in his last inspection report, states that "there is little to be said about the school, only that it is not and has not been for years, a success. With 40 children on the reserve, the attendance is very low and very irregular. Very few pupils get beyond the First Book, and even in that they cannot read with any ease or knowledge of what the lesson is about. Teachers have the lowest or no legal qualifications whatever, and easily get into a hump-drum, squaw-show-please sort of way, which at the end of the year counts nothing, except that they have drawn their salaries.

The present teacher, Miss Ethel Frost, has had charge of the school for a little over a year and her qualifications, the Inspector says are very low and she has had no success.

In November of last year the attention of the Bishop of Algoma was called to the Inspector's remarks on this school, which were somewhat similar to those quoted, and His Lordship was asked to secure the services of a competent and energetic teacher to take charge of this school after the summer holidays of this year. His Lordship promised to attend to this matter and he wrote to the resident missionary, Rev. Mr Frost, who is the teacher's father, and that gentlemen wrote the Department, taking exception to
the Inspector's remarks.

The Indians have contributed $1300.00 of their own funds for the erection of a modern schoolhouse with comfortable accommodation for a teacher. This building is now completed and occupied for school purposes only, as the teacher lives at home with her father. I think that with the salary of $300.00 paid by the Department and the comfortable quarters provided, the Bishop should have no difficulty in securing the services of a properly qualified teacher, without whom no good results can be obtained. When a good teacher is obtained, the Department can enforce the Regulations and compel a good attendance. The Roman Catholics have a school on this reserve, which is doing good work, and there is no reason why the Protestant school should not be equally successful.

I may add that the Department concedes the privilege of nominating teachers to the different religious denominations carrying on missionary work among the Indians in this district. If, however, the Bishop is unsuccessful in obtaining a good teacher, I think that the Department could, by advertising, obtain one.

The Deputy Superintendent General,

Re Leave of Absence to Mr. Hardyman.

On April 30, last, Mr. Hardyman, teacher of the Garden River (C.E.) school, applied through Dr. Gibson for an extension of his summer holidays to enable him to visit England. In view of his long service he was granted an extension of one month, till the end of September, and Dr. Gibson was told that, should Mr. Hardyman wish further leave, the services of Rev. Mr. Holland would be accepted as a substitute.

On June 7 Mr. Hardyman wrote the Department direct asking whether its intention was that the school should be reopened on September 1 and whether it would pay the salary of a teacher for September and October. He was told that additional leave had been granted him for the month of September but that if he wanted a further extension he would have to provide a substitute at his own cost.

From the above it will be seen that the Department intended to allow the school to be closed for the whole of the month of September and that a substitute was not to be furnished, unless Mr. Hardyman wished to prolong his absence beyond that time. The Department never intended to pay for a substitute, as Mr. Hardyman's salary is taken from the funds of the Garden river band.

My Lord Bishop, Mr. Ferris & Friends—

I am very pleased to welcome you all here this evening, and I thank our Bishop especially for honoring us with his presence. Last year was the first time our school had received official recognition by his lordship, and I know the reason he is here again is to impress upon us the importance of giving the children an education.

Give a child a good education, & it matters not whether he has a cat in his pocket or not.

It is an extremely difficult & slow business to create an interest in education amongst uneducated people, they will say, well I have managed to get along & I guess my children will pull through somehow.

But take a man who has been raised amongst every advantage educationally & he has wasted his school days, ask him whether it matters and he will tell you a different tale.

I came here tonight feeling more enthusiastic than I have ever felt, after 10 years of work on this Reserve; it seemed to me, I labored here for years, no one seemed to take the slightest interest in school matters but myself, except to find fault every now & then, & perhaps you may wonder what change has occurred to make me feel enthusiastic.
not till 6 months ago, children came to school when their parents felt like sending them, if they were old enough to help their parents at home. School was only a secondary consideration, as one person told him, on one occasion. To encourage more children to go to school as soon as there is nothing to do at home.

Since Mr. MacNab assumed office as Indian Agent, it is quite apparent he is determined to make the schools more successful than they have been in the past, so he has appointed a new Constable as Truant Officer, and children now of school age, in good health must attend one or other of the schools on the Reserve, if this policy has been carried out on the Reserve from the start when the schools were first established, what a difference it would have made by this time.

I am very glad to say, this new policy only started in last fall has been well received by the people, with one or two exceptions. I have no complaint to make, the same is being carried out at the Roman Catholic School, and in order to prove to all persons the benefit I have derived by Mr. MacNab's new policy, I obtained from his office the statistics of the present December just closed for the two schools for the Anglican Church of children in the vicinity of the school.

Thursday Jan. 14 was the Annual Prize Giving Day at the Anglican school at Garden River. Everything went off well. The Bishop of Algoma presided, assisted by Mr. A. D. McNabb, Indian agent, and Chief John Pino, who is the elder brother, John Pino, and W. J. Pino, stood as interpreters. The school was crowded.

The proceedings opened with a hymn, "O Come all ye faithful," one of the choirs presiding at the organ. The marks were then read, and the list of prize winners, and Mr. Hardyman made a report of the work done in Reserve. A very brief character sketch of each pupil was also read. The children then gave a piano and vocal recital, followed by readings and recitations. A committee consisting of Revs. C. H. Ferris and B. Fuller, Indians and whites, whose record was won by Phillip Stevens, his selection being entitled "People will talk." Dewey Wigwam was second, with "Fireside."

The Bishop gave a stirring address. He was pleased to see improvement, especially when he urged the whites present to do all in their power to uplift the Indian people. The Chief, and his brother, then gave an address. The entertainment closed with "Auld Lang Syne" and the National Anthem, and the Lordship pronounced the benediction.

The following letter from Mr. L. A. Green, B.A., Public School Inspector, arrived too late for the meeting:

C. F. Hardyman, Esq.,
Sir: I regret that owing to pressure of work I am not able to be with you at your exercises today.

I am pleased to give you this statement, however, for the pupils. The school has steadily improved in efficiency and in discipline; and with a little stronger co-operation on the part of the interested parties, success to the community will continue to increase.

By co-operation of parents, I mean the holding up of the standard as to duty, and acting in behalf of all for their own good. Many get the idea that they must be punished to pieces every time he does not do what the child or parent thinks he should do. This attitude may be different, but because they are that is no reason why he should not be upheld. The minute parents begin to show confidence in the teacher or the minister before their children, who are sitting in their feet daily, they see the usefulness of their lesson begins to fade. In justice to your children therefore support your teacher as a man worth the example to your children—a Christian gentleman—capable in many ways of teaching them the best patriotism, and the standards of morality so necessary for all boys and girls to receive at school and carry with them carry away. I trust we will have a successful evening and that this may be the beginning of greater things for the school this year.

Yours very truly,

L. A. Green, Inspector.

Dear Mr. Scott,

Our teacher in the Garden River Church of England school, Mr. Lucius F. Hardyman, has approached me upon the subject of the admission of Roman Catholic children to his school. I have told him that in my judgment it is very unwise to admit Roman Catholic children, lest the kindly relations between ourselves and the Romanists should be interrupted. I further said that I thought it was contrary to the avowed policy, if not to the rules, of the Department of Indian Affairs, for non-Roman Catholic schools to admit Romanist children, or for Romanist schools to admit non-Roman Catholic children.

Some time ago I found that Mr. Hardyman had admitted one or two Roman Catholic children to his school, and I then warned him of possible dangers in such a step. He did not at that time think any risk would be involved. Since then my apprehensions have been verified and trouble has arisen over the admission of the children alluded to above.

I bring the matter before you in order that the mind of the Department upon the subject I refer to may be obtained for our guidance in the future.

I cannot escape from the conviction that when two schools exist, for Roman Catholics and non-Roman Catholics respectively, in the same reserve, the wiser course is for us to be extremely careful not in any way to trench upon each other's prerogatives.

Believe me,

Faithfully yours,

George Algoma

MEMORANDUM

Mr. Scott

Mr. Hardyman, teacher of the Garden River Anglican, in his letter of the 18th instant, states that he is considering sending in his resignation as soon as something definite is decided in regard to his former application for a retiring allowance.

Mr. Simpson, M.P., who applied for a retiring allowance on behalf of Mr. Hardyman, was informed in September last, that the Department had no appropriation out of which a retiring allowance can be made to Indian school teachers. While this is the case exceptions have, in a few instances, been made in the way of a gratuity to teachers who have given their services for a number of years.

I may say that Mr. Hardyman has been continuously in the employ of the Department as teacher of an Indian school for the past twenty-eight years, first in the west and for the past fifteen years in his present position at Garden River. During all this period he has been untiring in his efforts to be of service to the Indians. While not a very successful teacher, he has exercised a good influence on the reserve.

Mr. Hardyman's salary for the past six years has been $600.00 per annum, which has been paid out of the band funds. With this salary he has had no opportunity of laying by anything and, should he retire, I think the Department would be quite justified in giving him a gratuity.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Meighen -

With reference to the attached communication from the Hon. the Prime Minister of Ontario, I beg to say that some time ago Mr. Hardyman advised the Department that he was considering sending in his resignation, provided something could be done for him by way of granting him a retiring allowance.

We have no provision for the retirement of teachers of Indian schools. It is true that Mr. Hardyman has given long and fairly satisfactory service to the Department as teacher of the Garden River Anglican Day School, but in the absence of any provision by Parliament for the superannuation of employees of this kind, I was unable to accede to his request. We have in a very few cases granted a small gratuity to retiring teachers, but this apparently is not what Mr. Hardyman has in mind. Under the circumstances I cannot see that anything can be done for him, unless in the way of granting him, say, three months' leave and allowing his salary to continue. I would be inclined to recommend this course.

Deputy Superintendent General.

MEMORANDUM

Hon. Mr. Neighen -

With reference to the attached communication from Mr. Inspector Green, of Sault Ste. Marie, I beg to say that we have carefully considered Mr. Hardyman's case. We allowed him a gratuity of six months' salary, which was the most liberal treatment that we could accord.

Mr. Green appears to be under a misapprehension regarding superannuation. There is no superannuation scheme at present in effect for any class of Civil servants, appointed since 1898.

As I have stated to you in previous memoranda, we appreciate the work that Mr. Hardyman did, and regret that there is nothing further that we can do for him.

Deputy Superintendent General.
My dear Sir,

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 6th instant, informing me that Mr. Harshman is not eligible for appointment to the position of teacher of the Indian school at Garden River.

I regret sincerely that I have given you needless trouble in this matter. I ought to have known that there would be difficulty in making such an appointment, but it never occurred to my mind.

I now wish to suggest the appointment of Miss Madge Ferris, the daughter of the Rev. S. H. Ferris of Garden River, as teacher in the Garden River school. As you will remember, Miss Ferris has been teaching in the school at Sheguianah, and has done so with great efficiency and acceptability. She has just been suffering from influenza and is on the point of resigning her school at Sheguianah, if she has not already done so. She will therefore be free to accept the Garden River school at an early date. I understand that Mr. Hardyman is desirous of completing the current quarter at Garden River, which will tide us over that difficulty, and I imagine the
Department will see no objection to that proposal.

I remain

Very faithfully yours,

Dear Sir;-

I beg to draw your attention to the fact that no teacher has yet been engaged for the Garden River Anglican Indian School. The difficulty seems to be that the salary offered is not sufficient to induce teachers to apply.

A few days ago we advertised for teachers for the school in the Children's Shelter near this city and stated the salary at $1200. The result was that we received 30 applications all from experienced well qualified teachers.

The remedy therefore in all cases where teachers cannot be secured seems to lie in the salary offered. My suggestion would be therefore that eventually the Department should take over the matter of the engagement of teachers for all such schools; meantime that the churches having missions among the Indians should be induces by an offer of higher salaries to place teachers with regular qualifications in them and that they should advertise the remuneration as equivalent to $1000 to $1200 according to the conditions.

If this was done I do not fear that any school would be closed for any length of time.

I have a number of applications in my possession now from the Children's Shelter that I would be glad to communicate with were it possible for me to do so, but I cannot because of the church and the Department lying between me and the solution of the problem.

I am writing you on the suggestion of Mr. A.D.McNabb and trust that this may be of some assistance in solving the difficulty.

MR. BUSKARD,

I have your memorandum of the 21st instant, requesting information as to the reason for dispensing with the services of Mr. Gilbert A. Sim, who taught the Garden River Anglican Indian Day School, on Reserve No. 14, Garden River Agency.

Mr. Sim was appointed teacher of this school on the recommendation of His Lordship the Bishop of Algoma, on January first, 1930. He taught until June 30th, following, when his services were dispensed with, on the recommendation of Mr. Inspector McCookin and Dr. Stone, of this Department. Mr. McCookin's report reads as follows:

"I visited the Garden River C. E. Indian Day School and found conditions most unsatisfactory. The classroom was positively filthy. It looked as if it had not been scrubbed or dusted for months. It was unfit for any Indian child to sit in. The teacher himself was disreputable looking in an old soiled khaki shirt and pants and unshaven. The conditions were such that I had thought of wiring the Department to close the school right away until another teacher could be found. Recently, Mr. Sim has taken a little boy of about eleven years of age from the Children's Aid Society to live with him. This is causing comment and criticism. To what extent it is justified I have no knowledge, but, on the grounds of general inefficiency, I have no hesitation in recommending that Mr. Sim be relieved of his teaching duties at the end of this present term. The school under the present management is a disgrace to everyone having any interest in it."

Mr. Sim was afterwards before the Juvenile Court, when the Indian boy he had living with him was removed from his charge. He is a frequent letter-writer. I am of opinion that this man is not quite normal in his mind, and I would suggest that little attention be paid to his communications.

Dear Mr. Crerar:

You may remember the writer of this letter. I had the honour to meet you some years ago at a banquet of the Ontario Prospectors & Developers Assoc. of which organization I am a past president. I also met you for a moment at Edmonton on returning from one of my trips to our mining operations in the Northwest Territories.

I am writing you to-day on behalf of a retired Anglican clergyman, the Rev. Lucius F. Hardyman. You may possibly have heard of him; he was a pioneer teacher among the Indians of the Sault Ste. Marie and Georgian Bay districts of Ontario and devoted over 50 years to administering to the natives. I have personally known Mr. Hardyman for 30 years, he was in charge of the Shingwauk Indian Home near Sault Ste. Marie for many years and also spent several years in charge of an Indian school at Sheguilandah at the east end of Manitoulin Island.

Mr. Hardyman is now wholly dependent on some dividends from his holdings in an Ontario gold mine, the future of which is very uncertain. Furthermore in the terrible bombing raid on the city of Bath, England, last April, he lost his home and effects; he and Mrs. Hardyman narrowly escaping with their lives. Mr. Hardyman is not a man to ask for charity, indeed would not accept it, but many of his friends including myself feel that here is a case worthy of serious consideration by the Dept. of Indian Affairs for a pension for his remaining years.

I am appealing to you rather than directly to the Dept. of Indian Affairs as I know you to be a man who knows the frontier life and the many hardships which a man like Mr. Hardyman must have experienced during his long service among the Indians, and that you will readily appreciate the circumstances of this case.

If there is anything you can do to help, I know you will use your influence in his behalf. Mr. Hardyman's address is 14 Johnstone St., Bath, England. If there is any further information you would wish I will be glad to secure it for you, or a letter direct to him at the above address would perhaps be more expedient.

Trusting you will not think I am presuming on your good nature and valuable time, and hoping for a reply in the near future, I am,

Yours respectfully,

(sgd.) J. J. Byrne.

Ottawa, November 26, 1948.

Dear Mr. Byrne:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of November 20, in which you ask that I personally consider the claims of the Reverend Lucius F. Hardyman for an allowance or pension from this Department.

The records of the Indian Affairs Branch indicate that Mr. Hardyman was employed for a period of approximately 30 years at Indian day and residential schools. It is somewhat difficult to state the exact period during which he was employed by the Government. I note from your letter that he was for a time in charge of the Shingwauk Home Residential School at Sault Ste. Marie. The officials are of the opinion that during this period he was an employee, not of the Government, but of the Anglican Church. The records do indicate, however, that he resigned from the position of teacher at the Garden River Indian Day School on March 31, 1919, and received at that time a gratuity from the Government equal to 6 months of the salary he had been receiving as teacher.

The principals of residential schools and the teachers of these schools are employees, not of the Government, but of the Churches, and are not eligible of course for superannuation allowances. Indian day school teachers are classified as temporary civil servants. However, these teachers have never at any time contributed to the Superannuation Fund and do not qualify for superannuation allowances. I find it difficult to see how an exception could be made in the case of Mr. Hardyman, particularly in view of the fact that no provision has been made in the estimates for

J. J. Byrne, Esq.,
Suite 52,
171 Yonge Street,
Toronto 2, Ontario.
the payment of such allowances.

I have been reminded by the officials that a number of requests, somewhat similar to the one submitted by you on behalf of Mr. Hardyman, have reached the Department in recent years. I regret to state that we have not, in any particular case, been able to make an allowance other than the gratuity granted at the time of retirement. The case now presented appears to be a particularly sad and deserving one and I can only express my deep personal regret at my inability to extend assistance to Mr. Hardyman.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sirs,

Regarding work of an extra-curricular nature conducted at this school.

Last winter we, the boys and myself, built the brooder house. We raised 303 of the 312 chicks. Gave 25 to each of ten families and kept 50 ourselves for the work. I bought lumber and have built a laying pen to be a double decker. I want to prove to the people here that there is money in hens if they are housed and fed properly. We have had the next batch of chicks for a week now and have lost six of the 311 we received. I may say that we got New Hampshire Reds in pullets because they are meant, I thought, to supply eggs for the diet of the Indians.

We have kept two cows all winter. We have raised a bull which is now ready for service. He is running in the common pasture with six cows. People are taking more of an interest in cows I believe.

I wintered a sow and had her bred last winter. She will farrow on June 11. My Indian neighbours have spoken for all she will have and more.

I have a couple of small patches of ground offered me by interested Indians. On one of them I am having a larger vegetable garden than last year. On the other I am trying an experiment to rid a patch of scutch grass from it. I am cutting the scutch grass the last of June, then plowing and sowing to millet which is a fast growing crop in hopes that after a year or two the millet will smother the scutch grass. The people here are hampered by this weed. On another small piece I am sowing a mixture of oats, wheat and barley and will feed it in the straw as we have no way of getting it threshed. It will be for hen feed. Then I am sowing some alfalfa as it is excellent for green feed for hens in winter.

Next year we are going to have a hot bed and will grow cabbage and tomato plants for the Indians. I can build it fairly cheaply and feel that it would be a great help.

Of course we have the garden at the school and with it we are planting hedges this year as well as the usual cleaning up which we didn't get done last year. In a few years time we hope to have it looking civilized.

Hoping you are in favour of this work, I am,

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

Dear Sir,

Since coming to this school four years ago I have been trying to persuade the Indian Agent, who is also Health Officer for the Indians, to have the children immunized by vaccination against Smallpox, Diphtheria and Whooping cough. Nothing has been done. This spring I received a supplement to the Guide for Dispensers which stated that teachers should not allow children to enter school unless they had been vaccinated. On Sept. 6 I wrote to the Indian Agent saying that I could not allow the children to attend school unless they were vaccinated. I set Sept. 16 as a deadline and sent a carbon copy of the letter to the Department at Ottawa. The Doctor made one excuse after the other and the last one was that he had no vaccine. Then the Agent ordered it from Ottawa and still there is no sign of vaccination.

After November 1st, I shall not allow any child to attend school unless he is vaccinated. None of them have so there will be no classes held until this has been done.

This Fall all the Indians were rounded up and X-Rayed in the Soo. A few were found to be infected. I believe all but two are willing to go to the San for treatment. One of the two has skipped out to the U.S.A., the other one is the mother of three children and she will not stay at home but persistently visits a home where there are eight children. I asked the Agent if they could not be forced to go. He said no not until they became a menace. If tuberculosis is active are they not a menace? Or has Medicine advanced beyond that theory since 1929.

Little need to wonder that T.B. is so prevalent among the Indians. A boy of seven years old was forced to walk three miles to school with tubercular abscesses on his neck. I had to dress them three different times and when they did not clear up I defied the Agent and Grunt Officer and sent him home. A person dies in the Sanatorium and the body is sent home. The coffin is opened and a three night wake is enjoyed by all. Then the corpse is dutifully kissed and buried.
This spring I ordered medicine in March and got it June. This Fall in September I ordered Medicine including Liver Oil which we need badly and so far have not received it yet. Why should there be such a delay now when the service was so good in former Years?

The children in this school are vile with head lice. I have kept sending them home for a clean up. This lowers the attendance. This spring a druggist friend of mine put me wise to D.D.T. That is the only way that I can keep them under control at all. I get tired of watching my wife comb them out of our little girl's hair and also got tired of combing them out of my own. The Indian Agent did not want to try to clean up the condition because he said it would be too much trouble. The lice breeders are still at large. This condition need not be as they have been cleaned up on the Oka Reserve where I taught for nine years and never saw a head louse, thanks to a wide awake doctor.

In the four years that I have been here we have never had an examination of the children's teeth, eyes or tonsils. This will soon have to be done as there are some of them who need attention.

We are paid $5.00 a month for dispensing and have to pay $1.75 a month for the telephone which is necessary so that we can get the doctor's advice. I may say that we cannot get the doctor unless we call the R.C.M.P. and have them stir him up. But you will see that for $3.25 a month we are on call 24 hours of the day. Never have so few done so much for so little.

It is to be hoped that you will be able to awaken some people out of their lethargy and get them to do some work.

Yours truly,

Albert Smith,

Ottawa, Ontario

I wish to acknowledge your letter of October 28th, addressed to Dr. Moore and complaining of conditions at the Garden River School. I am making arrangements to have the children inoculated and vaccinated, however, it is not necessary to exclude them from school until this is done.

Concerning the tuberculous patients, every effort is made to have the patients that are a menace, in other words, that have a positive sputum, admitted to sanatorium. I would point out that the preventive laws definitely state that patients with positive sputum can be forced to go to sanatorium. There are many cases of active tuberculosis that have not positive sputum and we cannot force them to take treatment.

The drug list includes "larkspur" for the treatment of head lice and this seems quite efficacious. I do not think it advisable to use D.D.T. for this purpose.

It has not been our custom to have dental and eye clinics for day schools and it is felt that if there is local work to be done the patient should be taken to the local doctor and he will do the work there, and if it is dentistry, send him to the local dentist. We do hold clinics for residential schools when there is a large group of children.

We cannot accept any responsibility for payment of the telephone in your house. The $5.00 a month you receive is for dispensing medicines and we do not see any connection between this dispensing and telephone charges.

W. L. Falconer, M.D.,
Actg. A/Supt. Indian Health Services

Mr. Albert Smith,
Teacher, Anglican Indian School,
Garden River, Ont.

The attendance on February 3rd, the day on which I inspected this school was sixteen. I tested only Grade 5 and Grade 7 with Achievement Tests and found them good in Spelling and weak in English and especially in Arithmetic.

This teacher seems to be in a rut and I feel that a change is definitely indicated. He admits frankly that he has lost interest in the lower grades and would like to handle the Senior Room at a two-room school. He is quite willing to move if we so request.

Discipline is no problem and the children are well mannered. They work well on their own and speak out well. The room is very untidy. In a corner is a work bench which takes up quite a bit of room (see recommendations below). The teacher was unshaven and his appearance left much to be desired in the way of cleanliness and tidiness.
This school is about fifty years old and has a large brick fireplace in the front of the room. This cuts down the blackboard surface considerably. The teacher's quarters are made up of a kitchen, diningroom/sitting room at the back. The whole is lighted with electricity and is adequately wired. The classroom has six semi-indirect lights in the ceiling.

RECOMMENDATIONS:

1. A brooder house at the back of the school should be fixed up as a small workshop and the Manual Training equipment should be moved to it. There is an old stove which can be quite easily put up in the workshop. It could also be used as a small storeroom for Scout and Guide supplies.

2. During 1949-50 we should have an Engineer visit the school and decide what can be done about the foundation. The building seems sound in spite of its age. The present teacher and the Agent seem to feel that the foundation could be dug behind the school and that the building could be moved back to this new foundation. We could then arrange to have it heated by a furnace and at the same time remove the brick fireplace.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Dear Sirs,

Last winter I wrote asking for septic tank toilets to be installed in rooms attached to the front of the school or else put a basement under the school and put them there.

An engineer came from Ottawa and took measurements and drew plans but so far there has been nothing done.

While making up a list of children with their ages for the Christmas tree list I discovered that within the next five years there will be 54 children of school age in this area. This will require a two-roomed school.

This class room is full now. There are 30 pupils with four due to start after Easter and I do not know where I will put them. I may add that the class-room is poorly lighted and ventilated and is out of date. The residence and class-room are both hard to heat. The toilets are too far away from the school.

May I suggest that a modern two-room school be built with basement for toilets, furnace and a water pressure system. It could also be used as a play-room and work-shop and should be the full size of the school building.

To Whom It May Concern.—Miss Edith Bockus has been known to me for about 15 years, starting from her engagement as School Teacher in the village of Arntfield Quebec. The school started as a one room establishment with Miss Bockus teaching all grades and subjects and its size varied with the fortunes of the nearby mines. At one time there were at least four teachers.

My connection with the school was as Mine Manager of the chief contributing mine and because of that position I shared the responsibility for the conduct of the school with the other Managers and representatives of the employees.

The record of Miss Bockus is impressive. She was held responsible by the committee for the teaching of the school and the administration. Apparently the system was that each assistant teacher was permitted to teach what she could teach best and Miss Bockus took the remaining subjects.

The school was a successful one and the graduates or those who moved from there to other schools were usually able to lead the classes in the next schools. One of her graduates, who took all her public school work from Miss Bockus and her first year high school, from her won the Governor Generals Medal for her matriculation work. Last winter five of her former pupils were students in this university.

I am pleased to recommend Miss Bockus to any teaching job that she thinks that she can handle.

Dear Sir:

I wish to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 17th instant. I wish to also point out various things which apparently you have overlooked.

First. I commenced at Garden River on Oct. 1st 1921 and taught until June 3rd 1923, thereby completing two years teaching at a salary of $800.00, making a total of $1600.00 which less one quarter salary, $66.66, namely $533.34 & have received $1400.00 only. I was not allowed to commence on Sept 1st 1921 as the preceding teacher did not complete her yearly service until Oct 1st 1921. This teacher was paid not only for the holidays in 1921 but also for Sept. although no school was held.

Secondly. Your Agent at Saint Marie
Our assurance was that I would receive my full proportion of salary for those holidays in the event of my resigning. I resigned with this assurance, and if this had not been so it would certainly have been worth my while to stay till Oct. 1st and receive a quarter's salary for a month work.

Thirdly, your Dept wrote me when I had almost decided to resign last year and told me they would be glad if I stayed for another year. Your agent also told me he hoped I could continue for another year. The Arch Bishop of Algoma said he would be very sorry if I should leave, and because of this I preferred a very much better position, not only in a monetary way, but in a city where there were a few conveniences and comforts, and possibly through my remaining here improve my wife's health.
seriously. I would also point out my resignation made effective from Aug. 31, 1923. I repeat I am entitled to my proportion of salary for the months of July and August, 1923, and I would appreciate your favourable reconsideration of my claim; I do not wish to cause you any inconvenience, but the fact is self evident, I have done the work and wish my salary. I may also say if you can not give me satisfaction direct I will be compelled to take it up through other quarters.

I am a returned soldier, and if you continue refusal of this, it will not coincide with your Dept policy toward us I hope.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Ottawa, January 5, 1926.

Sir:

The Department has received a communication from Miss Jane Johnston, teacher of the Garden River Anglican Indian Day School, in which she requests that the school be closed during the months of January and February on account of the absence of the Indians and that it be continued in operation during the months of July and August, next, instead. In this connection I would refer you to official letter of the 3rd ultimo, in which you were asked to discuss this subject with the teachers of both the schools on the Garden River Reserve, and to inform the Department as to whether you would approve of this arrangement or not.

The Department has decided, in view of the report of Miss Johnston as to the poor attendance during the two months, to allow the school to remain closed for the months of July and August, next, when she assures the Department there will be a more regular attendance of the Indian children, and Miss Johnston will be instructed to close the school immediately and reopen it again on or about the 1st of March, next.

Your obedient servant,

Dear Sir;

Your pardon please for this letter.
We are in great difficulty here of a financial nature. I mentioned at the post office, that we were still on the look out for our cheque. The Postmaster informed me that it would be paid at the end of three months time. We will not need it then because we can't live without eating.

Would there be any way you could arrange for me to get my cheque monthly? Really we are quite worried. We have used our savings in moving and getting settled. My son works in the saw mill boards here with us paying us $5.50 a week but the five of us could not live on that until Christmas. I never had any idea that I'd be paid different here from what I was at Oka.
Allow me to thank you for granting the materials necessary to make our home more comfortable and our work in school easier. The well was sunk to a depth of 38 feet but the water is still bad. As soon as I have made a few repairs to the residence and school I am going to dig a well on my own. I'm of the opinion that I can get water nearer the surface.

The building has "gone to seed" pretty well but in course of time we hope to have the plaster patched, the windows putted, and the loose boards back in place. We enjoy home-making.

The children and people are very very agreeable and it's a pleasure to work with them. So unlike the Oka people.

We have a warp on my small foot loom for school window drapes. Six of the big girls are weaving. They enjoy it too. I taught a grade IX and X and like the work with the pupils of all grades. My percentage attendance last month was 82.7%, not bad.

Whatever you can do will be very much appreciated.

Thank you again,

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith.

OTTAWA, 15th April, 1900

The Secretary:

I beg to call your attention to Mr Inspector McCaig's report on the Church of England School at Garden River in which he states that the school building is old and cold and that in his opinion a new schoolhouse should be built.

The present schoolhouse has been up for about forty years and has been repaired several times but I doubt if it is worth spending any more money in this direction. It was originally set up on cedar posts and it would not be worth putting a stone foundation under. The last time it was repaired was in 1894 when $100 was expended in sheeting the inside.

I visited the school on two occasions and fully agree with Mr Inspector McCaig's remarks.

In the fall of '95 the Department authorized the expenditure of $1000 from the funds of the Batchewana and Garden River Bands for the erection of a schoolhouse for the Roman Catholics on the Reserve and they have not a very commodious building, while the Protestant children are still in the dilapidated old schoolhouse above referred to.

I think that $700 would put up and equip a school suitable for the Protestant children and that such an amount could not be better expended.

Sir,

I have the honor to call your attention to certain clauses in the specifications for the erection of the Protestant School House at Gordon River in the clause relating to the erection of the fire place and chimney in the school house. The first clause calls for a brick chimney with three stories from the foundation. It then provides for an open fire place inside, not in school room. If the fire place be built it is absolutely necessary to have it more than half a brick thick so as to prevent carrying the fire from heat of fire place over into the school house. A third clause provides that the fire place shall be constructed behind the fire place.

There's another suggestion that I would make and that is that the interior of the building be fitted with rough lumber. The building in the school room especially will be scarcely strong enough to keep the flue from breaking without the lumber. The extra cost would not be more than $40.00 and I should strongly urge this to be done as well as building the thickness of wall of fire place which should also be protected by a screen around the front.

Ottawa, 10th June, 1902-

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 2nd Instant, relating to the construction of the Protestant Schoolhouse on the Garden River Indian Reserve, I have to say:

1. The fireplace should be built in the usual manner, that is, not less than one brick thick. The Specifications refer to the chimney only, as being half a brick thick.

2. The cold air duct to the stove in the Schoolroom is constructed by boxing the joists from a register which should be placed under the stove to the outside wall, and continuing the same through and up the wall to the bottom of the window sill. The top of the duct is to be covered with wire netting.

3. The Specifications provide for the walls to consist of studding 16 in. apart. On the outside rough boarding, tar paper and clap boards, on the inside lath and plaster, two coat work, except under the wainscoting where only one coat is to be placed, that is to say the wainscoting is placed in position when the walls have received only one coat. This is considered to be quite sufficient without the extra boarding which you mention, and necessary furring under the lath and plaster.

Your obedient servant,

Memorandum for the Secretary.

With reference to your enquiry regarding expenditure in connection with the Protestant Indian School on the Garden River Reserve, I beg to say that an Order-in-Council passed in November 1900 authorized an expenditure of $1100.00 from the Capital funds of the Garden River Band for a combined school house and teacher's dwelling for the Protestant Indians of the reserve. The outlay incurred exceeded the amount authorized by $40.70. It is thought it would be well to obtain another Order-in-Council authorizing an additional outlay of say $200.00 from Capital to cover the over expenditure of $40.70, and to defray the cost of seats (which Mr Benson estimates at $100.00) as well as to meet any incidental expenses.

Accountant.

29 Aug 1903

Dear Sir,

I have recently taken charge of this school, having been compelled to leave the North West on account of my wife's ill health. I have been engaged in Indian work for many years and have always received good reports from your agents and school inspectors.

This school is very well situated & I consider it properly handled shall be a credit to the Dept.

I have had a good fence put up, a garden 25' x 30' dug, also borders all round the fence in which there is room for nearly 300 trees which intend to plant next spring. My intention is to make this place a model school both inside & out.

We are very much cramped for room, having to live in 3 small rooms upstairs and besides the doctors here say it is exceedingly hard on my wife's health when we run up & downstairs so much, and we must have a little built as a lean-to. I have a plan which I will like the Dept to sanction the old school which is still standing a mile from here, could be pulled down, so the material of it used...
To make us a kitchen, the only material we will require will be tar & lining paper, nails, & shingles; I am digging a well which will be inside this proposed kitchen, and as we will require a cellar to hold our winter supply of vegetables I propose to dig one under the kitchen in the opposite corner. It is absolutely necessary for us to have a cellar and also more room as we have a family, and unless we can have this improvement granted us it will be impossible for us to manage this winter, so trust although so late in the season that you will see your way to approving of this addition, as the Indians have approved this plan to me and if you will lend us a little assistance I shall set the work all done free of cost by the people, it will be necessary to lose no time as the winter commences early in this part of Algoma.

I have the honor to be

Your obedient servant,

Henry F. Hardyman.

Specification for the erection of the Protestant School House at the Garden River Reserve.

Description.—A two story frame building on a stone foundation. Size, 38 feet by 22 feet 6 inches, Height of the ceilings to be 12 feet and 9 feet respectively. It is very desirable that the front of the building should face eastward in order to secure the best lighting of the school-room.

Foundation.—Plain rubble masonry. The walls are to be 20 inches thick; 3 feet 6 inches in the ground and 2 feet above; they are to project 6 inches beyond the face of the outside walls so that the building can be brick veneered at any time.

Build a pier, 16 inches square of brick or stone, with a footing course 2 feet 6 inches square and 6 inches thick, at the centre of the building to receive the 10 x 12 inch beam running crosswise under the school-room floor.

Lay 2 inch plank on the top of the walls.

A half brick thick chimney with two flues 8 x 8 inches and a vent 8 x 12 inches. Put in a register to the vent at the school-room floor, and make a pipe hole to the flue in the school-room and two in the flues in the room above. Provide and fit stoppers and the necessary soot boxes and doors complete. Carefully parge the flues throughout their length.

Ventilators.—Put six iron ventilators in the outside walls of the building, three on each side of the building.

Lay a suitable cold air duct from the outside to the stove; with a check damper to regulate the supply of cold air to be worked from the inside; also pro-
provide a galvanized iron jacket to inclose the stove around the back and sides and extending to the floor; properly framed and secured to the floor.

Floor Beams.—The ground and first floors are to be supported where shown by dotted lines in the drawing; for the ground floor by a 10 x 12 inch pine beam, 22 feet long, supported in the middle by a pier already mentioned; and for the first floor by a 15 inch steel I-beam—41 pounds to the foot. This beam will appear below the ceiling of the school-room and is to be supported at its ends by 10 x 10 inch pine posts built into the side walls of the school-room and firmly footed on the 10 x 12 inch floor beam. Chamfer the angles of the posts appearing in the room.

Joists.—The floor joists of the ground and first floors are to be 2 x 12 inches and 2 x 10 inches respectively set at 2 ft. centres.

Double joists under the partitions and 4 inches thick joists for trimmers for the stairs and chimney breasts.

Lay two rows of herring bone bridging on each floor.

Ceiling joists are to be 2 x 8 inches set at 2 ft. centres and well nailed to the rafters.

Flooring.—Lay a 1 inch thick rough diagonal flooring over both floors over which lay a finished floor of 1 1/4 inch dressed tongued and grooved boards of narrow widths and selected quality for the school-room floor.

Blind nail.

Studding.—The studs of the walls and partitions are to be 2 x 4 inches at 2 ft. centres. Double and securely braced at the corners of the building and at windows and door openings.

Wall plates 2 x 4 double.
Wall.—The outside walls are to be boarded on the inside and outside with 1 inch rough boarding and covered with tar paper. Clap board on the outside.

The inside of the walls and partitions and ceilings are to be lathed and plastered in two coat work, and hard finished.

Roof.—The rafters are to be 2 x 8 in. at 2 ft. centres. Cover the rafters with rough boarding and tar paper. Shingle with best sawn cedar shingles, 5 in. to the weather.

The hips and ridge of the roof are to be covered with weather boards and roll.

Flash the valleys of the roof and the base of the chimney at its junction with the roof with galvanized iron.

The eaves, corniced and gable ends are to be neatly finished with 1 in. dressed boards.

Doors.—The entrance door is to be in two halves, each 2 ft. 3 ins. x 7 ft. 1 3/4 ins. thick, with upper panels glazed and with transome lights above as shown on the drawing. This door is to be provided with a strong serviceable lock and two keys. On half of the door is to have two 3 in. bolts, top and bottom, so that it can be closed fast while the other half is open.

The other doors (excepting the one between the vestibule and school-room which will be 3 ft. x 6 ft. 8 ins.) are to be 2 ft. 8 ins. x 6 ft. 8 ins. four panelled and chamfered 1 1/4 ins. thick and provided with suitable locks, handles, etc. The two doors to the school-room are to have transomes. These transomes with the one at the entrance are to be hinged or pivotted and fitted with fixtures for opening and closing them from the floor.
Windows.— The windows will be of the sized and number of lights as shown on the drawing. The two windows in the rear of the school-room are to have boxed weights, pulleys, etc., complete, to both upper and lower sashes. All other windows will have their upper sashes fixed, the lower ones movable. Provide and fix all necessary fixtures. Window glass of a good quality to be used. Double thick glass for the front door.

Architraves.— Carry simple architraves, at least 5 ins. wide, around the windows and doors and a 10 in. wide base board around the walls of the school-room and rooms upstairs.

Put a simple chair rail with a cap around the walls of the school-room and vestibule also around the walls of the kitchen and living room.

Hooks and Shelving.— The vestibule of the school-room is to have four dozen strong clothes hooks in two rows 4 and 5 ft. respectively above the floor. These hooks are to be spaced 9 ins. apart and the top row is to be over the spaces of the lower row.

Provide and place two dozen wire hooks in the living-room and bed-room closets and in the hall.

The kitchen closet is to be filled up with shelves for a pantry.— Construct a fixed table where shown in the kitchen with three or four drawers under the same.

Platform.— Build a raised platform 5 ft. x 8 ft. and 8 ins. above the school-room floor where shown on the drawing.

Blackboards.— The wall spaces behind and to the left of the platform, from 2 ft. 6 ins. to 7 ft. above the platform and floor levels, are to be painted on the plaster with prepared blackboard paint. Form a ledge 5 ins. wide along the bottom of these blackboards to hold the brushes and chalk.
Stairs.—Build stairs to the first floor where shown on the drawing in a neat substantial manner, width of stairs 3 ft. 6 ins. twenty risers, 9 ins. treads. Simple handrail balusters and newel posts.

Gable.—Build a gable over the entrance as shown on the drawing also the platform and steps.

Painting.—Prime and paint in two coat work with white lead and linseed oil paint of approved colors, the whole of the woodwork both outside and inside usually painted. The girder across the ceiling will receive two coats of paint. Finish in a light blue color.

General.—A plain good substantial building complete in every respect is to be erected of sound material and good workmanship. It is to be subject to the inspection and approval of the Indian Agent.

Note.—The seating of the school-room and the stove are not included in the contract. For the size of the stove around which a jacket is to be made inquiry must be made of the Indian Agent.

Sir,

I have the honor to advise you that the water at the well belonging to the Church of Our Mother School has been for some time very unfit for use owing to it coming from a source of decayed vegetable matter in the vicinity.

At the time the well was sunk it was impossible to go deeper and apparently the water was good. Now however it is unfit for use.

Sir:

I have the honor to present the request of Jacob Wagimah sub-constable of Garden River Band to purchase the old school building standing on the Reserve. It appears that the building is being torn down gradually and disappearing, probably for fire wood. As a building it is of little value but there is a quantity of good material in it which would probably be worth ten or fifteen dollars. Wagimah is willing to purchase it at fifteen dollars ($15.00) or if the Department is not willing for him to purchase he asks that it be put up at auction and sold to the highest bidder.

If it was put up for sale I do not think it would bring any more than the amount offered and would suggest that his offer be considered.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

Dear Sir:

I beg to refer to F.153806/5A. I am much pleased to know the Dept. takes a keen interest in this School; so I have, & will continue to do so, told the Indians so, because I feel that owning this Reserve being so
close to Sainte-Clotilde, that this school should be as good as we can make it.

I give the pupils marks for all their lessons, also for 'prompt attendance' at the two sessions, & 'conduct,' & I gave in all 33 prizes to the 5 classes viz 4th Book, 3rd Book, 2nd Book, 1st Book, Primer, &c.

national Anthem.

taught; & after that I delivered the

invited to partake. The educational
value of this entertainment was the

Mr. Ogilvie,

You will note in the letter below the suggestion of the Indian Agent with regard to improvements at the Garden River (C.E.) School. I am sending you the file on which the plan of the school is and I would ask you to suggest how the chimney should be improved and whether any other means of ventilation could be provided, except by having the windows lower from the top.
May 26, 1917

I have examined the plan of Redden River C.E. School, also the report letter regarding the boiler and chimney.

The easiest method of providing better air is by taking out the block from under the top brick and lowering same about two inches and firmly secure in place. If it is necessary to close the window and cut the concrete bricks and cement frame into third or even fourths of what it will both the cement fixed and partly back but not broken.

Regarding the chimney, it will appear necessary to remove the portion above roof and rebuild in cement masonry. The chimney should also be raised at least six inches higher than it is now to provide a flue of 9" diameter to still further increase height of chimney smoke pipe.

With fresh air admitted to the class room, and sufficient chimney to effect chimney to provide him with the accompanying benefits, they should have fair ventilation although the building itself is rather smaller than is usual for a number of that size [accommodating 70 children].

[Signature]

P. M. [signature]
March 26, 1912.

Memorandum,

Mr. Scott-

I have examined the plans of Indian River C.E. school, also the agent's letter respecting the ventilation and chimney.

The easiest method of providing cold air is by taking out the blocks from under the top sash and lowering same about 2 or 3 inches and firmly secure in place. If it is necessary to close the window, rods cut the correct length, and secured to frame with string or wire (to prevent loss of rod) will hold the sash tight closed and firmly lock both sashes.

Regarding the chimney it will apparently be necessary to tear down the portion above roof and re-build in cement mortar. The chimney should also be increased in height to give better draught, also to provide a glazed 9" drain tile to still further increase height of class room smoke flue.

With fresh air admitted to the class room, and sufficient draught in chimney to provide heat with the arrangement there, they should have fair ventilation, although the ventilating duct is rather smaller than is usual for a room of that size. (accommodation for 20 scholars)

Dear Sir:

I am pleased to report that the school playground outfit has been completed, and the work done satisfactorily. Mr. MacNabb I hope will inspect the same. I supervised the work and assisted.

The work could not be duplicated in a white village under $40. To complete the work, I found it necessary to paint the whole outfit, otherwise the ladder etc. would have spread, being green wood.

Mr. Green, our Inspector, has kindly consented to inspect the work and report to you. It was recommended by him in his annual report to the schools under him.

And the Educational Dept. of Ont. in its Bulletin issued to all teachers says, "Ground alone without equipment for play is somewhat like a school without blackboards or maps."
The man, John LePage who did the work, has not charged for the timber he required, and he also repaired part of the fence around the school garden, which required 8 new cedar posts & rails, so I trust that although the cost is over the amount estimated & allowed by the Department that you will consider I have acted wisely in the matter. Dear Sir:

It has always been my endeavor to keep expenses down as much as possible, but at the same time, I consider it my duty to the Department to keep the school & its surroundings in good repair, and a credit to the country.

There is urgent need to have one or two things attended to before the cold weather sets in, viz.: I have no decent cellar to keep my vegetables, the cellar, when the kitchen was added, was never finished, consequently everything freezes in it. In the spring, a foot or so of water soaks into it, I well suspect then it dried either with stone or bricks, and cement floor, & ceiled in, and ventilated.

The roof in one two places leaks, & if not attended to the ceiling upstairs will fall to pieces, and the wood shed also leaks badly.

I think there ought to be a second chimney built, because our chimney is not sufficient, and I cannot heat the upstairs.

I have not asked for any improvement.
The Anglican School

Garden River, Ont.

To the teacher's apartments since the addition was erected which is ten years ago, so I feel it imperative to do something in order to save expense both of the delays and than no place to keep vegetables or plants in our winter.

I proceeded to Sault Ste. Marie on the 29th ultimo, and on Wednesday the 30th ultimo, Mr. McNabb and I visited Garden River Reserve and the Shingwauk Home. While at the Garden River Reserve we visited Mr. Hardyman at the protestant school, and I wish to draw attention to the needs at this school. Their supply of water is not satisfactory and a new well should be sunk outside of the building, the present one being in the basement. This simply involves the driving of a pipe and water will presumably be found at no great depth. A new pump should also be provided.

The school building is in need of painting and the interior of the building should be kalsomined. A hardwood floor should also be laid in the class-room.

The surrounding grounds are as usual, in excellent condition and a splendid object lesson for the Indians. Mr. Hardyman has quite a large lawn and I think he should be furnished with a lawn mower, and I would recommend that the agent be authorized to purchase one for him and to have the work above mentioned done.

Sgd. A. F. Mackenzie.
Ottawa, August 6, 1925.

Sir,

Mr. MacKenzie of this Department, who visited the Garden River Protestant School on the 30th of June, last, with you, states that their supply of water is not satisfactory and that a new well should be sunk outside of the building; that a new pump should be provided; that the school building is in need of painting and the interior of the building should be kalsomined and that Mr. Hardyman, the teacher, should be furnished with a lawn mower.

You are hereby authorized to have a well sunk outside the school, to have the building painted and the interior kalsomined and to purchase a pump and lawn mower for this school.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In reply to your letter of the 11th Inst re account for painting the Anglican School.

I beg to say that I had a conference with Mr Sawyer and he insists that he only charged the regular prices for all the materials and labor. He also says that he or any of the Master Painters would not out of the City they invariably charge and collect 50¢ an hour and Board and Lodging. In this case he went himself and took pains to have the work done right.

If the work was done by the yard it would cost within 17¢ of the amount sent you.

I thought it would be cheaper to have it done by commission and as he was there himself I felt confident he would do the right thing which he did.

The building was given 2 coats of paint on the outside and it required a large amount of paint on account of the building being badly weather beaten. This is not an ordinary school and dwelling. It is a school and dwelling combined with two lean to sheds a wood shed and two closets. The lean tos are connected with the house the woodshed and closets are separate. The inside of the school building was very much in need of painting and I had him paint it.

The windows in nearly every case had to be reglazed and in several cases he put in new glass. Inside the School building the plaster was badly broken and it took a lot of time to repair it before Kalsomining.

I agreed to him having 10% commission if he would look after the job himself and work at it in place of sending men to do the work.

I am enclosing you statement of cost of work by the yard at the regular prices and as I said before there is a difference of 17¢
