Extract from Teacher's Annual Report for year ending March 31, 1921. Garden River Anglican School. 160370-27F. Ontario

BUILDING:- Walls and ceiling very dirty. Windows need repairing.

FENCE:- Posts and barbed wire, Out of repair.

Residence for Teacher.- In bad repair.

I wish that the local agent would see that the necessary and long neglected repairs to building are made.

A door from schoolhouse to schoolroom would be an untold blessing in winter. This could very easily be made from sitting room.

Mrs. Beatrice Stephenson.

Teacher.
OTTAWA, April 26th, 1921.

Sir,

The teacher of the Garden River Anglican Day School in her annual report for the fiscal year ending March 31st, last, states as follows:

"The walls and ceiling of school building are very dirty and the windows need repairing. The fence is out of repair and the teacher's residence is in bad need of repair."

The teacher also requests that a door be made to allow entrance from the sitting room of the residence to the school, and states "this would prove a blessing in winter".

I have to request that you will furnish a report as to the repairs needed to school, teacher's residence and fence, and furnish an estimate of the cost of having the school room walls and ceiling cleaned, windows repaired and the necessary repairs made to the teacher's residence, the door suggested by the teacher put in, and the fence repaired.

You should furnish this information at your earliest convenience in order that if it is decided to have any work done, it can be performed during the coming summer holidays.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. D. McNabb, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 26th Ult No 13-2-5 in reference to the Garden River Anglican School. The Teacher complains about the Walls and Ceiling of the School no doubt the School and Teachers Quarters are in need of cleaning or rather Kalaminining, but I am of the opinion that the Teacher and her Husband could do a great deal to make the place look different to what it does, when Mr Hardyman was there the Anglican School and grounds was the beauty spot along the Trunk Road from the Sault to Thessalon, and he did not ask for any very great expense. The Fences were in good shape when the present Tenants took possession, The House needs Shingling and I was doing that last summer but when I got an estimate of the cost of doing the necessary repairs I knew it would not be any use to have it done then as it would cost nearly the price of a new building. In regard to the Door she wants if this were done it would spoil the building, I would not under any consideration recommend that this door be cut through, I cannot conceive what she wants a door there for, if it is not so she can have a better chance to watch her Husband who occasionally gets wrong in his mind. I admit the place wants repairing and cleaning and I estimate it would take from two to three hundred Dollars to put it in shape, I would also suggest that when the Building and place is put in repair that a new Tenant be also supplied in the person of a Qualified Teacher, I do not think that this School should be a refuge for retired English Church Clergymen or their Wives. The Scholars in this School has not had a chance to show what can be accomplished, Mr Hardyman was not a Teacher, and the present incumbent is worse, While Mrs MacNabb was teaching the Pupils showed what they could do if they had a chance there is more than English Church Catechism to be taught let the Church look after the religious instruction, and the Teacher learn them the three R's.

I do feel keenly about this School and you may think I am putting it too strong when I say that Indian School matters should be taken out of the hands of the Clergy and be looked after by the Department through the Agent, then if the Agent does not do his duty replace him by a man that will, Education is what is wanted in the world today.

Hoping you will send me a good Qualified Teacher for this School after the Summer Holidays,

I have the honor to be Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Indian Agent,

J. D. McLean Esq,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 22nd instant, regarding the repairs required to the Garden River Anglican Indian Day School.

In reply, I beg to say that you may arrange for the purchase of the shingles required to reshingle the roof. You should obtain a good grade of clear cedar shingles. Before making the purchase you should obtain competitive prices from a number of dealers and purchase the quantity of shingles required from the dealer quoting the lowest price for the grade of shingles required. You should then arrange to have the work of putting on the shingles done by day labour.

You may also arrange to have the kalsomining done to the interior of the teacher's residence. You should purchase any material required after obtaining competitive prices.

When the work is completed, you should forward properly receipted vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred, and you should attach a memorandum showing the firms asked to quote prices on the material required and the quotations received.

The Department will leave the matter of repairs to this building in your hands, and you should exercise close supervision over the work, and see that it is done as cheaply as possible and to your satisfaction. It is hoped that you will be able to have the work done during the present summer holidays.

The Department agrees with you that it will not be necessary to have a door cut between the school room and the teacher's residence.

It is noted that you will have the repairs required made to the fences.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 26th instant, furnishing a report on the condition of the Garden River Anglican Indian Day School building and teacher's residence.

In reply I beg to confirm the following telegram of today's date regarding the work required to be done to the kitchen:

"May have painting, cleaning and repairs required made to kitchen Garden River Anglican School."

Regarding the work required to be done to the other portions of the building, I beg to say that you may arrange to have the walls and ceiling of the basement whitewashed, and the hall and stairway and upstairs rooms of the teacher's residence washed and kalsomined, and the woodwork and floors painted. You may also arrange to have the walls and ceiling of the school room washed and kalsomined, and the woodwork painted and the front steps repaired. The closets should also be cleaned and whitewashed, and put in a good state of repair.

The Department will leave the above work in your hands to make the best arrangements you can for the carrying out of the same, and at the lowest possible cost. Only the work absolutely required should be undertaken. The painting, cleaning and other work should be carried out during the present summer holidays, and completed at as early a date as possible.

If you purchase the material, competitive prices should be obtained, and in that case the work should be done by day labour. If, however, the contract is given to a decorator, you should obtain prices from a number of persons competent to do the work, and the contract should be given to the one quoting the lowest price, which should include the cost of all material and the labour employed. When the work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the expenditure incurred.

You may purchase the linoleum required for the kitchen. While serviceable material should be obtained, it should be purchased as cheaply as possible. Competitive prices should be obtained, and the purchase should be made from the firm quoting the lowest price. You should forward properly certified vouchers covering the cost.

We will expect you to see that all the above work is completed in a satisfactory manner and at a reasonable cost.

Your obedient servant,

Extract from Teacher's Annual Report on the GARDEN RIVER C. E. DAY SCHOOL for the year ended March 31, 1925. See 1925A-1F. ONTARIO.

Building—Stone. In fairly good repair. The water runs under from the eaves as there are no eavetroughs or water carriers on the building. This causes the floor to raise up and swell in places in times of rains or dampness from the spring thaw.

Ottawa, March 26th, 1925.

Sir:

The teacher of the Garden River Anglican Indian Day School, in her annual report for the current year, states, in referring to the condition of the building, that there are no eave troughs or water carriers on the building, and, as a consequence, the water enters the building, causing the floor to raise up and swell in places. She also states that the woodshed is in bad condition, and that, as the roof is broken, the shed cannot be used.

I have to request that you will furnish a report regarding the placing of eave troughs on the building, stating whether you would recommend that this be done, and, if so, the approximate cost of the same. Please also report regarding the condition of the woodshed, stating what repairs are required, whether you would recommend that the work be done, and, if so, the cost involved. Your early reply giving full information will oblige,

Boys' closet had broken seat and filthy carvings. It is on the same side as the girls' playground. The girls' closet is at the rear of the boys' playground. I suggest the boys' be repaired and used as girls' closet, and that boys use the one at the rear of their playground.

Ottawa, April 29th, 1926.

Sir:

The Public School Inspector, in a report on his recent inspection of the Garden River C. of E. Indian Residential School, states as follows regarding the condition of the closets:

"Boys' closet has broken seat and filthy carvings. It is on the same side as the girls' playground. The girls' closet is at the rear of the boys' playground. I suggest the boys' be repaired and used as girls' closet, and that boys use the one at the rear of their playground."

You will note the Inspector's recommendation regarding the change in the use of these closets, and also that the boys' closet be repaired.

You should take immediate steps to have the boys' closet repaired and placed in a satisfactory condition, and if you approve of the Inspector's suggestion that this closet be used by the girls, you may have the change made. I have to request that you will inform the Department as to the work you have undertaken in the repairs and whether you have made the change in the toilets, as recommended by the Inspector.

The Inspector also states that there is a depression around the pump and that water lies there and drains back into the well. You should arrange to have a few loads of gravel placed around this pump. This matter should also receive your early attention.

No unnecessary expense should be incurred in the repairs to the closets and in the levelling of the ground around the pump, and, when the work has been completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In looking over the Anglican School at Garden River recently, I found some repairs that should be made.

The chimney above the roof should be torn down and built up new from the roof up, as the smoke is coming out around the roof, and there is danger of fire.

Also the hardwood flooring in the school, has heaved up in places 4 and 5 inches, this should be taken up and relaid, the dampness underneath has caused this trouble.

The building is on very low ground, and the water runs in under the foundation and is destroying it. It requires about 25 loads of filling to raise the ground around the building to allow the water to run off.

The above repairs would probably cost around $100.00. If the department wishes a more definite estimate I shall be glad to have a mason go down and look over the chimney and make a further report.

Ottawa, June 18, 1929.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 14th instant, enclosing an estimate of the cost of the painting and repairs required to the school building, teacher's residence and outbuildings at the Garden River Anglican Indian Day School.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of your arranging to have this work carried out during the coming summer holidays. You should purchase the paint and any other materials required, obtaining, if possible, competitive prices. You should see that a good grade of material is obtained. The school, sheds and outhouses should be given two coats of paint on the outside, and the interior of the schoolroom and porch one coat. The painting of the teacher's residence should also be carried out as mentioned in your detailed estimate, and all repairs as mentioned should also be completed. The Department will expect you to see that all work is carried out in a satisfactory manner.

This work should be carried out by day labour under the charge of a competent foreman, and you should keep proper time sheets of all labour employed. Should you require an advance to pay the labour, same will be sent you upon request. A supply of blank forms is enclosed herewith for the keeping of the necessary labour returns. You should see that these are signed in duplicate by the individual labourers employed and certified by yourself.

It is noted that you estimate the cost of the painting and repairs, etc., to be approximately $330, and this amount should not, if possible, be exceeded. You should forward itemized accounts, in duplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of all material.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.,
June 19th, 1939.

EX'D.

Dear Sir:

This is to advise you that I have inspected the Garden River R.C. school and the Anglican school.

The roof on the south side of the R.C. school is badly in need of repairs. I think that it needs to be reshingled. Also the cellar needs fixing as it floods after every rain and in the spring it is usually full of water.

The Anglican school needs redecorating inside. Also a new and better outside toilet is required and other minor repairs.

I would suggest that you give me authority to have a competent carpenter look over both schools and make me an estimate on the cost of repairs needed to put both in good shape.

Yours very truly,

Robt. P.G. Laurence.
Indian Agent.

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Re: the enclosed requisition:

(1) The paper on the walls of the living room is badly cracked.
(2) Kalomine is for the living room ceiling.
(3) The linoleum in both living room and kitchen is worn out in some places and patched in others. We are using our own linoleum in the bed rooms and halls.
(4) To close holes in plaster around doors and windows and to fill small holes and large cracks in plaster.
(5) The paint has fallen off the glass in most windows in both school and residence.
(6) There is a lock on the front door of the school and the lock is broken. It must needs be a sturdy lock set for this.
(7) One glass broken in window in girls' toilet.
(8) The glass is broken in the cellar window and the seal is rotted so that new glass cannot be installed.
(9) This lumber will be used for shelving, cupboards, and topping saw work in school.
(10) For boys craft classes.
(11) One piece of plaster has fallen off the ceiling upstairs. Would make a better job with lye rock than acid plaster.
(12) For the four school windows, there are only two blinds and only one of them will roll. By using pulleys and such end I will have them unroll from the bottom upward.
(13) Water barrel needed for rain water. The well water is too hard for washing or scrubbing.
(14) For the residence, I will supply the posts and put them in myself.

For all the repairs above I will do the work if you supply the material requested.

(15) See next page.

There will have to be a new well dug.

There is a well here and plenty of water in it which tests all right but does not taste right and when left standing overnight forms an oily scum on its surface and discolors the vessels in which it was standing. This water purely is not fit to enter the stomach. We are forced to carry drinking water for school and residence a distance of 3/4 of a mile.

The well water is so good for cooking, washing, scrubbing because it is too hard and when boiled it turns yellow.

This is a pipe well fitted with a pump. The pipe was pointed driven. It is Indiana clay, it is 14 or 16 feet deep.

Some of the opinion that the well should be dug to a depth of 20 or 24 feet. By going deeper we would pass the strata of mud from where, I gather, we are now getting the water.

Two good men working for 5 days should dig the well. It should be fitted with cement tile about 24 inch diameter or large enough for a pail to enter it. Smaller tile could be used if the pump was re-installed. Some think the iron pipe should not be used but I see no reason why the pump and pipe could not be used as it is not from the pipe that we get the iron in the water.

Every school should have a good well as every child should be entitled to good drinking water.

Thank you for your attention,

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith.
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.
October 16, 1942.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed herewith please find Requisition received from Albert E. Smith, Teacher of the Garden River Reserve C.E. Indian Day School, for material required to make necessary repairs to the School and Residence.

Mr. Smith is prepared to do the work himself, provided he is supplied with the material requested.

The total cost of material required is approximately $55.55. As the repairs and improvements requested are all necessary, I recommend that the material be granted if possible.

Regarding the well, everything Mr. Smith states in his enclosed letter is correct. The water from the well is not fit to wash or scrub with, nor for drinking. The previous teachers at this school have been single persons and, therefore, did not require as much water as Mr. Smith will need, as he is married and has a family. It was not such an inconvenience for them to get water from a distance. For this reason, nothing has been done about the well in the past but an effort should now be made to get more suitable water.

I am of the opinion that the well should be driven deeper in an attempt to get better water. The approximate cost of material and labour to do so would be $50.00.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir,

During the two vacation months July and August it would be necessary that I obtain work in the Sault. Before seeking employment elsewhere I should like to know if your Department would consider retaining me here for July and August for the following reasons:

First. The fence enclosing the school grounds here is in very bad shape. The wires are sagging and the posts need straightening. Some posts will have to be replaced. I could do this by getting my own cedar posts in the bush and borrowing a stretcher for the wire.

Second. The $30. which the Dept. allowed towards cleaning the grounds was well spent but the task was such a big one that there is still a great deal to be done yet, such as trimming of trees and small underbrushing. Then I want to prepare the ground all along the fence so as to be in a position to set out a hedge of cedar next spring. That is cedar along the back and ___ two sides but Locust across the front.

Third. The front porch on the residence needs jacking up and the foundation replaced. The porch has sprung away from the house owing to the fact that in former years ice was allowed to gather on its roof.

Fourth. There are three woodsheds which all need repairs before winter sets in. The stable roof also needs some patching. Of course it has to be jacked up at one corner and plastered. I would like to whitewash the interior of the toilets and put a better urinal in the boys' toilet than the makeshift one I put in last fall.
Fifth. I had hopes of having the school building painted this summer. The walls are in a very poor condition. If that is to be done I should like to be here to see that it is well done. Before any painting could be done the whole surface would have to be gone over and loose boards nailed in place and then brushed with a stiff steel brush. I know what needs to be done and I can do it or see that it is done right. I want to take out the windows and fill in around them and putty around the glass not only the school windows but those of the residence. The windows in this building are very cold and I know the cause. I want to do as much of the inside painting as possible since I have to spend my time in the room I do not want to see a patchy job.

Sixth. When the school was moved four or five years ago to allow for the new highway it seems that the whole building was jacked because the walls have parted company at the corners. I have repaired the walls in three of the rooms but there is still the class-room and three rooms and the hall upstairs to do yet. I want to build a small bathroom upstairs using part of the hall-way for it. There is an old chimney upstairs which has been partly torn down. I have to finish taking it out before we can do very much fixing at the two front bedrooms. The base-board and quarter round will have to removed and plaster put in the space between walls and floor. The floors are very cold and that is the reason for it.

Seventh. Two families are making additions and repairs to their homes this summer. I should like to lend them a hand. I have interested a great number of people in gardens. I would like to help them off and on. I am experimenting on the growing of sugar beets here also have a few apple and plum trees which I want to keep pruned. I can see that the Agricultural Society here is depending on me a great deal and that will take extra time this summer. I am trying to interest the young folks in softball. And I do not want our Young Peoples Club to go flat for two months.

Eighth. Take into consideration that the residence has seven rooms, the grounds cover almost one and a half acres and nothing has been done in the last 15 years to amount to anything until we came last fall.
If you wanted any information as to the work we have done here you might write to Rev.B.P.Fuller. He has been an interested spectator and a great help in our work here. If this extra work is not done this year it will spread over three or four years and I don't want to have too many outside interests next term because I will have four in the Entrance class and they will take a lot of time.

Before closing I should like to thank you for the appointment to Garden River. We all like it here very much. We like the pupils, people and the place. The agent, Mr. Laurence, has been very helpful and we appreciate it very much especially after having lived at Oka.

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith

3. Repairs to the front porch on the residence;

On your next visit to the reserve you might again inspect this building and let me know what repairs you feel are urgently required at the present time. In the event of your recommending additional repairs, an estimate of the cost should be supplied.

R.A. Hoey,

Dear Sirs,

About this well at the school here.

Last fall you gave $30 towards it. With this money we bought pipe and had two men drive the point down 24 feet. We got water but it was full of iron and oil. Then I dug and found a spring which we used all winter and well into the summer but then the spring dried up. I then tried the pump again but found that the point was broken as we got sand and silt in the water. I had a man help me raise the pipe and of course the point did not come. Then I dug again down a few feet farther in hopes that I would be lucky enough to strike another vein of water but did not succeed. We are now carrying water for half a mile.

I shall, therefore, need a new point and two men for about three days to work in driving it for water. We need a pipe wrench to take the pump and pipes apart. The wrench will be kept here and will be the property of the school. I have had to buy one to replace one I borrowed and which I had taken away from me, so I am not borrowing again.

It is absolutely necessary that we have water here and good water too. Not only for the children and my own family but if the place was to take fire it would burn to the ground and there could be no insurance collected because of the lack of water.

Yours truly,

Albert E. Smith.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

The lumber and tools are required for the Manual training periods.

The Well point is needed for the well.

Kindly advise if it will be in order to hire two men for three days to work in driving the new well point for water as requested in Mr. Smith's letter attached herewith.

Memorandum:

MR. HONEY

Re: Garden River Reserve Anglican Day School

An inspection of this school was made on June 28 in company with Mr. Laurence. Mr. Smith, the teacher, was interviewed. For some time the Smiths, who occupy an upstairs apartment in the school, have been complaining of the roof leaking in a number of places. The present condition of this roof is such that further patching is of no value, as the number of leaks increases every time any weight is placed on the roof.

A small addition to the school on the West side is being built by Smith. It is a closed-in porch approximately twelve feet square. I understand he is giving his labour gratis. The purpose of the porch is primarily to stop draughts, but also to provide additional space to the apartment.

A price to reroof the school and the porch was obtained by Mr. Laurence from a local contractor, on a material-plus-labour basis, of $350 and I am of the opinion that approximately this amount will be required. I would recommend that authority be given to reroof this building.

This school also requires painting, but I consider that this might be done another year.

W.S. Arnell,
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

August 21, 1944.

I have your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to allowance for lunches at the Garden River C. E. School.

We will allow the same amount as last year, namely, $6.00 a month, for the months of November and December, 1945, and January, February and March, 1946.

I am a little surprised at the statement made in Mr. Smith's letter, to the effect that the majority of the children attending his school have little or no breakfast before coming to school in the morning.

In view of the payment of family allowances, it is reasonable to suppose that the Indians are better able to provide food for their children, and certainly, the Department would appreciate anything you can do to bring to the attention of Indian parents their responsibility in this regard.

The fence around the Garden River Indian Day School C.E. lot requires 19 new posts and the wire tightened. The cost of labour and material to do this work would be approximately $12.00.

Kindly advise if it will be in order to have this work done.

R. F.G. Laurence
Indian Agent
Sault Ste. Marie Ontario.

RPGL/cwc
Ottawa, March 29, 1946.

Mr. R.F.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

With reference to your letter of the 25th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $12.00 for labour and material to repair the fence at the Garden River C. of E. Indian Day School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

Ottawa, April 2, 1946.

Mr. R.F.G. Laurence, Indian Agent,
Sault Ste. Marie, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of the 30th ultimo, you may purchase a new kitchen stove for the residence at the Garden River Anglican School. The price quoted by the teacher, namely, $80.00, appears high. Possibly you could secure a suitable stove at a lower cost.

You may also purchase the following articles:

- 33 sq. ft. of Masonite, for table tops,
- 30 ft. moulding, for applying Masonite,
- 2 door locks,
- 1 pint green paint,
- 3 quarts white paint,
- 10 rolls wall paper,
- 12 " ceiling paper.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
